article-text.p: The annual Open Enrollment period begins today (Monday, October 25) and ends at 5 p.m. on Tuesday, November 23. This is the time of year to review your health and welfare benefits and decide whether to make any changes. Unlike recent years when there were relatively minor changes to plan options, the plan changes for next year are significant and present several important decision points. Please take the time to become fully informed as action is required on your part if you choose to adjust your elections.

p.span: Significant changes for 2011 include the following:

Please be aware that due to rising medical plan costs UC is making major changes in medical plans, with premiums for some plans increasing substantially. Two new medical plans (Health Net Blue & Gold HMO and Anthem Lumenos PPO with HRA) are being introduced as value-priced alternatives for next year. Providers used by many UCSC employees under the current Health Net HMO are not available under the lower priced Blue & Gold HMO. For an overview of these changes, please see the Preview of New Medical Plans for 2011.

li.p: Your children up to age 26 are eligible for UC insurance plans that provide coverage to children (subject to collective bargaining). If your children reached or will reach the age of 23 at any time in 2010, you must re-enroll them during Open Enrollment. UC will not re-enroll them or continue their coverage automatically.

p.span: Health Flexible Spending Account funds may no longer be used for over-the-counter medicines such as aspirin, cold medicine, cough drops, etc. unless you have a prescription for that medication.

If you are a represented employee, medical plan contributions and certain eligibility changes that are not mandated by federal law may be subject to collective bargaining negotiations. However, plan changes must still be made during Open Enrollment. Please see Information for Represented Employees.

article-text.p: Open Enrollment booklets were mailed to your home last week. For individual assistance, please contact the campus Benefits Office at (831) 459-2013.

We fully recognize that this year presents special challenges for our campus and that the changes in medical plans present difficult choices for a large number of UCSC employees. For those who elect to change their healthcare provider, the campus is dedicated to supporting you in making that change. Please refer to the UCSC Open Enrollment website for helpful information. lead-image.image-caption: UCSC professor emerita of philosophy Ellen Suckiel

secondary-images.image-caption: Mary Rorty, clinical associate professor at the Stanford University Medical Center and faculty associate at the Stanford Center for Biomedical Ethics

article-text.p:
Designer babies, genetic perfectionism, the selling of human body parts--are these morally desirable outcomes of the latest developments in scientific research?
Advances in Biotechnology and Medicine: Stretching the Moral Boundaries is just the beginning of a new series of ethics lectures that will be presented by the UC Santa Cruz Humanities Division.
The series is made possible by the Peggy Downes Baskin Humanities Endowment for Interdisciplinary Ethics, a fund created in honor of her longtime interest in ethical issues across the academic spectrum.

“There are so many areas in which ethical problems arise--in journalism, politics, medicine--and the endowment emphasizes the need to address these issues in a cross-disciplinary context,” said Baskin.

For the inaugural lecture, UCSC professor emerita of philosophy Ellen Suckiel will discuss the potential moral difficulties brought by advances in genetics, particularly the paradox of “genetic perfectionism.”
She will be joined at the event by Mary Rorty, clinical associate professor at the Stanford University Medical Center and faculty associate at the Stanford Center for Biomedical Ethics.

Suckiel noted that while current and upcoming practices in biotechnology and medicine have distinct benefits for human health and well-being, they may at the same time erode longstanding and valued concepts of respect for the person.
She said that Rorty will address the ways in which people--or their body parts--are sometimes considered as “property.”
“The question is: Is it appropriate to buy a body part?” Suckiel asks. “Are your organs yours to sell? You can go to China or India and buy a kidney, but in the United States, they don’t allow it.”

“Is your body part your property?” she adds. "In the U.S., it is not considered your property, although you are allowed to sell eggs and sperm. It’s also OK to give away a kidney; you can donate a kidney in the U.S.--but you can’t sell it.”
Newly retired in July, Suckiel has taught ethics at UC Santa Cruz since the early 1970s. As provost of the campus’s Stevenson College from 2004-2010, she introduced a number of ethics courses into the college curriculum.
“The more that we can study ethics in our society, the better we’ll be able to fight debasement and divisiveness in the world today,” Suckiel noted.
“There isn’t sufficient reflection on ethical issues, and if there were, I think we’d find that people would be much more supportive of each other,” she added.

article-text.p: (Unit Managers: Please post a paper copy of this message and all related materials for people in your area who do not have regular computer access.)

I'm writing in anticipation of Open Enrollment, which begins on Monday, October 25. I want to encourage you to evaluate your options carefully, particularly those related to health insurance. Specifically, the cost of Health Net HMO coverage is increasing dramatically, which is a change that will impact many UCSC employees. The Academic Personnel and Staff Human Resources offices are working with PMG (Physicians Medical Group), the local provider for the lower-cost Health Net Blue and Gold option. PMG assures us they have capacity, and they will be on campus during the Open Enrollment period to meet with employees.

Many of you have shared your concerns about these rate hikes and option changes with me, both at meetings and via e-mail. I understand the hardship they pose, and I share your displeasure. I was actively engaged in conversations with UC colleagues at the systemwide level that I had hoped would provide some relief. Unfortunately, the news is not good. All plans are final, and no changes are forthcoming.

span.span: On Monday, you will receive a letter from the Academic Personnel and Staff Human Resources offices announcing the start of Open Enrollment. Please give thoughtful attention to the options presented. You may want to look closely at other health insurance plans that might not have worked for you in the past. To help you evaluate your choices, our Staff Human Resources office will host several workshops throughout Open Enrollment, which ends November 23 at 5 p.m. Details about those workshops and other resources are available online at:
. Please monitor that site for news and updates.

article-text.p: Cordially,

Alison Galloway
Campus Provost and Executive Vice Chancellor

article-text.p: (Encargados de la unidad: Favor de imprimir una copia de este mensaje y todos los materiales relacionados para las personas en su área que no tienen acceso regular a una computadora.)

Escribo en anticipación del período de inscripción abierta para sus prestaciones, que comienza el lunes 25 de octubre. Quiero animarles a que evalúen sus opciones cuidadosamente, sobre todo los relacionados al seguro médico. Específicamente, el costo de la tarifa de Health Net aumentara dramáticamente, un cambio que afectará a muchos de los empleados de la Universidad. El departamento de Recursos Humanos del Personal y la oficina de Recursos Humanos Académicos están colaborando con PMG (Physicians Medical Group), los proveedores locales para la opción de bajo costo Health Net Blue and Gold. El PMG nos asegura que tienen capacidad y estarán en la Universidad con nosotros durante el periodo de inscripción abierta para reunirse con empleados.

En las reuniones y vía correo electrónico, muchos de ustedes han compartido sus preocupaciones sobre los aumentos de las tarifas. Entiendo la dificultad que plantean, y comparto con ustedes su disgusto. Participé activamente en conversaciones con los colegas en el liderazgo de la Universidad de California, con las esperanzas que podrían ayudar. Desafortunadamente, no hay buenas noticias. Los planes están finalizados, no habrán cambios.
